review_text: I just finished Paper Lily and saw this, so I had to give it a try and honestly, Project Kat is every bit as good in its own way. It’s shorter and more compact, but that actually works in its favor. The whole game feels like a tightly crafted introduction to this universe, with the same eerie charm and unsettling atmosphere that made Paper Lily so memorable. The storytelling is really sharp. Kat herself is a great protagonist sarcastic, curious, and just a little reckless and the game uses her personality to pull you into situations that feel harmless at first but slowly twist into something much darker. The puzzles are simple but clever, the choices feel meaningful even in a short runtime, and the branching paths make it worth replaying just to see how differently things can unfold. What impressed me most is how much mood it manages to create with such a small space. The lighting, the quiet sound design, the little moments where the environment shifts when you’re not looking it all builds this creeping tension without going for cheap scares. By the end, you can really see the foundation of everything Paper Lily expands on. As a free prologue, it does exactly what it needs to: it stands on its own while making you want more. If you’re into atmospheric horror adventures with personality and style, Project Kat is absolutely worth the playthrough.

10/10 in my opinion. I am a big fan of rpg horror but have only come across a few good ones that I can truly say I have enjoyed in every aspect. Project Kat is extraordinary at packing so much bite into such limited amount of game play. I could even go back for a second play through [to get all achievements] and didn't find myself getting bored or restless. This is probably due to the fact I left the bottom left storage door untouched in my first play through and then circled back afterwards to pick the lock. I also replayed the game after inviting the three girls to join me in the ritual. After inviting them to your "party" they will follow you throughout the game, similar to the mechanics of corpse party except they are always present and never "one" with Kat. This expanded the dialogue ten fold and pretty much tripled the interaction and reaction box responses. Just a brilliant short story that unfolds in an incredibly interactive and thought provoking way. Could be approached as a mind invigorating weave of puzzles to unfurl or, if you're feeling more casual, you can approach it with an in and out easy approach. Versatile and layered. Would recommend.

[h1] Project Kat - Paper Lily Prologue [/h1]
[h2] Score: 8.5 / 10 [/h2]

I went into this expecting another forgettable RPG Maker horror game, but Project Kat hits different. It's got personality, player choice, and a main character who’s just the right mix of smug and doomed. The art style? Adorable and creepy in equal measure. The little animations, the subtle jokes, the atmosphere — it’s all made with the kind of love most games can’t fake. I’d almost call it charming, if I hadn’t sworn never to use that word in a review.

It’s spooky without being cheap, and the choices genuinely affect how things unfold — even if they all seem to lead to the same deliciously ominous end. My only real complaint is that it’s over just when things start to get juicy. But hey, it’s free. And it’s technically a prologue. So I won’t deduct too many points for that.

A.B.O verdict: Project Kat is short, stylish, and way smarter than it looks. Just don’t expect closure — it’s here to open a door, not close one. And even if, you'll nose nothing by trying a free game.

For more reviews, check out the curator page:
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/abocuratorpage

One of the game’s strongest points is player choice. Many puzzles can be solved in multiple ways, and decisions — even small ones — have a noticeable impact on the narrative. The attention to detail is admirable, and the soundtrack adds to the eerie mood perfectly.
As a prologue, it does its job exceptionally well: it introduces the world, teases larger storylines, and leaves you wanting more. I’m genuinely excited for the full Paper Lily experience.
A short but powerful prologue that delivers atmosphere, mystery, and smart design. Highly recommended for fans of story-driven psychological horror.

This is a great game. I played it [i] after [/i] playing Paper Lily: Chapter 1 because I'm not the brightest, but there doesn't seem to be a downside to it. Both games are amazing, this one is just much faster and much more intuitive than the Paper Lily game. 

Pros:
- The soundtracks are good, the music is well fit to the scenes, not irritating 
- The controls are good, too. It follows the generic RPG type of control system but works well and nothing feels necessarily irritating to press. 
- I like how many options you have within the game, some options leading you to different endings, but some just being little interactions that don't necessarily count towards the story but are your own way of doing things. I love the emphasis at the beginning that there is *always* another way of doing something!
- The art is amazing, I said this for Paper Lily and it holds true for this too. Both games are very well polished, run amazing and I just can't believe that either or both are free!

Cons:
- The puzzles aren't inherently as hard as Paper Lily. In some cases this is good, the use of objects that you pick up makes sense, you can figure out the "secret" interactions yourself. However, I feel like the game was a bit too straightforward i.e. all routes and achievements were done without the need to consult a guide. 
- It's surprisingly short, and the True Ending yet again just feels lacklustre like Paper Lily. The game, story progression, all the ins and outs of the game are so good but both True Endings just feel so... meh
The game is amazing. A little story that I can highly recommend to everyone.

Despite looking like an RPGM game, it isn't. It's actually made in Godot, which really confused me at first. But despite imitating RPGM, it plays well—at least for a demo.

The story is similar to Corpse Party (I should replay that sometime). Our heroine, Kat, decides to perform a ritual at school since she's really interested in them. She gathers the necessary items, weird things start happening, and she must decide whether to go through with the ritual or not... (Before that, something important happens, but I won’t spoil it. I'll just say it’s actually a well-written section.)

Gameplay wise, it's very similar to other RPGM horror-puzzle games. You gather items, use them in specific situations, and progress. You can complete tasks in different orders, which leads to multiple paths. While your choices do affect the endings, many of them ultimately lead to the same conclusion just with a different flavor. That’s not necessarily a bad thing. (Some of the endings were actually different from the *classic* **"you died the end"** type, which is great.)

Controls, art, and music are all in the same boat—they’re okay. Nothing really stands out, but nothing is bad either.

Using the Godot engine while incorporating RPGM-inspired gameplay has some potential. Since RPGM is a really limited engine, this could allow for more unique gameplay sections, which I hope to see in the future.

Overall, it's a great demo (I guess it is?). Since the game is free and short, I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys this kind of game.

For a free game, Project Kat exceeds my expectations. It pulls you in with the story, creepy world building, and the atmosphere develops without the use of cheap scares. Even though the characters are designed in pixel art, which I find super adorable, and I love that there is a constant sense of dread lurking beneath the surface.

What caught my attention is the attention to detail in your choices. The puzzles are fun and easy, and the game does not confine you to a single way of thinking. The game is short but replayable, and it is finely crafted. Those who are into psychological horror or narrative driven games should certainly try this.

If you are looking for a short RPG horror game, this is one of the game you might want to try.

As for the gameplay, you play as Kat, a student who sneaks into her school at night to perform a ritual.

Your mission is straightforward, help Kat collect the items needed for the ritual & perform it (or maybe not)

The game has multiple ending, so what you choose to do will affect the ending.

There are puzzles involved, but nothing too difficult.


The early part of the game does a great job hooking you in and making you curious what the game is really about.

The storyline maybe a bit predictable...
(Well, obviously you can guess what's going to happen when you perform a ritual at school, especially AT NIGHT)

But predictable doesnt mean it is boring.
I really enjoyed the game.
It does a good job of making the school seems unsettling & making you feel isolated at certain part.

I replayed the game many times just to get all the ending.


Btw, incase you've tried this game & liked it, I recommend checking out Paper Lily - Chapter 1.

But a bit of warning, it is more challenging than Project Kat. The puzzles are more difficult and there are lots of enemies wanted to kill you.

Project Kat is a short indie horror game about a teenage girl who dabbles in occult rituals. It relies on subtlety for its horror aspects, rather than shoving loud sounds or jumpscares in your face. The save system (which is consistent even in the followup game, Paper Lily) is extremely lenient, allowing up to 30 save slots, of which I only needed to use about 12 within Project Kat, and reached the end of Paper Lily at the 30th slot exactly. The game is very short, only lasting about 50 minutes for the primary route, but most of the decisions you make throughout the entire game lead to different endings. There are many different endings, and I was able to get all of them in just under 90 minutes, so there's not a ton of effort to experience all the story has to offer. The music also goes crazy, especially the club theme.

It's a short game in the Paper Lily franchise, so it can't be bad. But somehow I was more disturbed by this than Chapter 1, and I already was pretty disturbed in Chapter 1. Project Kat is a really good game, all that being said. Bravo. Bravo indeed.

Game Name: Project Kat - Paper Lily Prologue
Overall Rating: ★★★★☆ (4.5/5)
Reviewed by: Horror game obsessed Femboy

As someone who played a good amount of horror and psychological horror games like cry of fear and such, I can confidently say its got a lot of polish in its design and story telling. You play the game as Kat a very nonchalant, smart, and kind of sarcastic girl with a fascination with the occult. Thankfully the game doesn't rely on jump scares to make it enjoyable, instead it builds the atmosphere through the music, pacing, and subtle story building. The consequences of your choices are shown to have an impact and matter even from the beginning of the game. 

Now lets go in depth.

Gameplay: The controls are simple and can be remapped as needed. The game has a unique system regarding interacting with models, etc. There are multiple paths and small choices that branch into different scenes; there is also really fun puzzles and mini games as well. It respects your time and need for adventure.

Art and Sound: The pixel art for me has always been a big selling point in games, Project Kats specifically is very clean and expressive, but what I really enjoyed was the sound design. Subtle ambiance, strategic silence and some music really added up to a great horror immersive experience. 

Narrative: What I love most about Project Kat is how it doesn't tell you everything. It lets your imagination fill all the empty spots which makes the horror feel much more immersive and scary. Kat's personality is well written she is courageous, confident, and curious.

Length: It is a very short game, only about 45 minutes of game play to an hour. 

Final thoughts: If you're into psychological horror that prioritizes immersive gameplay and respects your time over cheap gore—while adding in mystery and meaningful choices—then Project Kat is a must-play.

Short, Stylish, and Full of Potential

Project Kat - Paper Lily Prologue surprised me in all the right ways. On the surface, it looks like another pixel-art horror RPG with anime-inspired visuals and cryptic puzzles — but what sets it apart is the clarity of its tone, the confidence of its pacing, and the subtle ways it plays with genre expectations.

From the opening moments, Project Kat establishes a strong mood. The atmosphere is eerie but not overbearing, and it doesn’t rely on cheap jumpscares or gore to build tension. Instead, it leans into psychological unease — making you question the rules of its world, and slowly tightening the noose of dread as you push further into the unknown. And for a game that lasts less than an hour, that’s no small feat.

What impressed me most, though, is how polished and deliberate everything feels. The writing is sharp and understated. Kat — the protagonist — is refreshingly self-aware and skeptical, which adds a grounded edge to a story that could’ve easily drifted into cliché. The game manages to keep things ambiguous without being incoherent, letting players piece together fragments without holding their hand.

The puzzles are relatively simple but well-integrated. More importantly, the game offers multiple paths and solutions, hinting at a deeper branching narrative system that’s likely to be expanded in Paper Lily. That sense of hidden depth — that there’s more under the surface — is part of what makes the experience so compelling.

Visually, it nails the aesthetic. The spritework is expressive, the use of lighting is clever, and the limited animations are used at just the right moments to deliver impact. The music is sparse and moody, never drawing attention to itself but always reinforcing the unease.

If there’s any downside, it’s only that it ends too soon. But then again — it’s a prologue, not a full game. And as a teaser for what’s to come, it’s a triumph. It doesn’t just promise a great game in Paper Lily — it earns your curiosity and your trust with its craftsmanship.

Project Kat is a rare thing: a short indie horror experience that doesn’t feel derivative, doesn’t waste your time, and leaves you wanting more for the right reasons. If you’re a fan of narrative-driven horror with a psychological twist, this is absolutely worth your attention.

"Project Kat - Paper Lily Prologue"  is not a game.  It's an advertisement for a product called "Paper Lily".  Paper Lily is an RPG construction kit asset flip slapped together badly, but never finished, the first chapter was dumped on Steam as another advert for the product which never eventuated.  Like all JRPG construction kit garbage, it's just a collection of complete cringe high school anime club dropout writing with assets ripped off from the construction kit, plus a few really crappy low quality 2D assets that may have been sourced elsewhere.

But this isn't completely relevant because this is not Paper Lily, it's just an advertisment for it, so it's not correct to try to review that completely distinct product.  We must instead review this for what it is... an advertisement.  If you enjoy advertisements, you can consume them for free on the web or on Youtube without needing to add them to your game library, download them, and then launch the advertising.  It's impossible in a general sense to recommend people should do that over playing real, full games on Steam, and that applies here with "Project Kat - Paper Lily Prologue" too.

The purpose of this advertisement, given there's no actual product to buy, is just to get you to give the "developer" EIGHT BUCKS to support them... wtf?  They want you to pay them $8 for this advertisement.  What a joke.  What weird beggarware.

This is only free in the same way that adverts on Youtube and banner ads in your browser are.  This is a game demo that's been dumped on Steam to advertise another Steam store page in the hopes of raking in some cash.  Just because advertisements are free, doesn't mean they're worth your time.

It's important to understand there's a formal process to create a demo/page for a game which hasn't been followed here:

https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/store/application/demos

While it might seem like an inocuous mistake, publishing demos and advertisements as if they are full games is misleading and in some ways harmful.  This advertisement is taking up marketing space and visibility that would be better made available to a developer that's done the right thing and created a full game.  Instead, that visibility is given over to a demo/advert that's been published incorrectly and is polluting the marketplace.

It's unclear if this mistake was made through incompetence or a deliberate intent to mislead gamers.  Often developers may choose to incorrectly publish demo/advertisements as separate games as a cheap way to bypass paying Valve for marketing presence on the Steam front page, which may seem clever to them, but it's harmful behaviour and it's not good for gamers.

Advertisements and incorrectly published demos don't add +1 to your game collector count, they aren't full games.  It's impossible for me to recommend this incorrectly published advertising spam to gamers, you deserve better than adverts.

Now THIS is how you do an RPGMaker inspired horror game. Even though the game is very short, it effectively builds the atmosphere, slowly building up the creepiness factor without relying overtly on jumpscares or anything of the sort. The main character Kat is really interesting and likable. It controls really well and also there are some fun things you can do like accidentally breaking a light switch and cutting someone's hair. The art is also really charming for each of the characters and the music, despite being very little is very fitting for the mood.

Definitely recommend giving this a try especially since it's free. It's 1000000% better than anything Ann could do.

I was never really a fan of game graphics such as this game. What do people call them? 8bit graphics? But man did I fall in love when I played this game. Yes it's a "horror" game, and I mean a HORROR game in the sense where the atmosphere, soundtrack, sound effects bring the "scary" bits and feelings, not as the usual that the horror genre does - jump scares.

The game itself has very very basic gameplay controls and it's incredibly easy to play. As for the story - it's great! It went by so fast when I was completing the story, hunting for the other achievements etc. and since the title has Prologue in it's name, I really want to see the next chapters that Leef6010 will bring, hopefully soon! 

All in all, incredibly fun game, true to the genre, easy controls, nice story, amazing atmosphere, great sound track!
Recommended with both hands ♥

"Project Kat" is an RPG maker horror game. In the game, we play as a female protagonist named Kat. She is in a school at night and disturbs the other 3 girls in the occult club's room cause she's preparing to do her own ritual. She's done many rituals before but none of them ever worked out. But she is recklessly doing another, hoping that a ritual will work out this time. Will it? Yes, unfortunately for her. She opened a one way gate to hell and the devil is laughing at her stupidity and mocking her. Pretty understandable. Will she escape and survive or die in despair? You'll find out once you play this game.


"Project Kat" shows the stupidity of doing rituals and the consequences of that. The graphics of this game are really beautiful. As an RPG maker game, it's made in pixels but when we see the characters and pictures, we see how beautiful the art is. Also, the soundtrack is really stunning. It suits so freaking well and gives the perfect vibe to the game. The place where the story takes place is itself perfect. The abandoned dark school, with all those rooms, while doing a ritual. Gosh, this game has such a good vibe. 

I highly recommend playing in that game. It's a wonderful adventure. And it's free so it's really worth it.

So much fun! This sweet little game has the perfect mix of story, comedy, puzzle and creepy without being to much or to overwhelming for those who don't do well with horror games. I usually don't play games of this art style/gameplay but I loved it! I highly recommend giving it a try for yourself; I will be eagerly waiting for the full game!

If you're new to steam and trying out free games, something you may not realize until later is that whenever you see 'prologue' it's actually just a short demo (usually the beginning) of the game. It's a neat way of catching players attention towards an upcoming game and/or sometimes if the game is still in development it can be a way to work out any possible bugs or polish up areas that they didn't think of until players pointed it out. It's mostly the former than latter, though. 

With that said, I had fun with this! It's always fun when a game gives you many ways to solve a problem (such as you can use a lockpick when you find a hairpin or ask for a key for the theater door). As far I can tell, there's definitely some consequences of what you do decide to do (such as there's subtle hints via the environment changes). And just like many RPG Maker games I hope it'll be quite replayable with various outcomes to uncover.

Hello there!                                                                                                       Rate: 09\10

I see you are wondering whether this game is worth your time, well not to worry, you came to the right place! Below this i will separate this game and express my thoughts and feelings about them which in turn i hope helps give you a better insight to the game and give you more of  an idea of if you want to play!

Before we continue, please note that these views are mine alone and i realise others may differ so please have an open mind.

(NO SPOILERS)

First impressions - I came across this game whilst looking for something new and exciting that could provide me with enjoyment, the first thing i knew i liked about it was the art style! and once i saw the game style i had taken a quick glance at the rating by other players and hopped straight into it.

Art style - I have taken a liking of the art since i first saw the game and after playing, i can say it has not disappointed me at any point. Something about it just holds a simplistic look to it yet very well done. The characters are clear to be designed well and environments even more so. 

Characters - Something i must praise is that they put personality in the characters and it is clear they are realistically different from each other. Though they do not have a back-story to them, you feel as though you get to know them a little playing the game. As i said before the models for the characters are pristine, simplistic but well polished.


Controls - They are simple and easy for the player to use and in some parts make the game satisfying.


Story - It may not be the longest story, nor a complicated one, but you often find yourself feeling like you right there in the game with them while playing along. It is also somewhat realistic in the reasoning they have which is always nice, with what the story is based on also makes it that bit relatable. 

Simplicity- It is quite simplistic which i feel is a great attraction to this game, it isn't complicated and is fun and easy going.

Duration - It personally took me around an hour and a half (1 hour 30 minutes) though this does also include re-plays. In short, it is a quick easy game.

Achievements - Not too many to overwhelm the player and they are quite fun and easy meaning achievement hunters should take interest.

My experience - I, for one, can say i enjoyed playing the game and think of it often as it is a memorable time playing. At no point was i tired of the game, it kept my interest all the way through and i hold it as one of my best games i have had the pleasure of playing.

Re-play aspect - I myself have not re-played it fully as of yet but i have had a wish to at some point as i enjoyed my time and i think it will be a game that you can easily play again.

Thank You for giving me your time and in doing so i hope i was able to give you a little insight into the game and what you might get out of it, i hope i was able to help any doubts you may have had and if you do choose to play the game then feel free to let me know how you felt about your experience down below.

So this is a fairly new pixel horror adventure game that I am indeed looking forward to, and i must say it is really good and its worth checking out. 

Well since the prologue is very short and sweet i won't spoil the story, there seems to be a super mysterious vibe to it. I just loved how polished the artwork is. Its a fairly new modernized pixel game and you can tell that instantly. Loved the alternative endings so far, strong occult and supernatural vibes, but i didnt feel that much scared playing the prologue except reading the ritual instructions. Not only there are alternative endings but alternative actions too which is quite unexpected, so the game is heading on the right direction. 

This game is worth being voice acted, it's super great and the CG character art isnt bad either. Characterization of the main protagonist is pretty good of what i saw, she is a skeptic and this is a horror game, so far so good. To the devs, all i can say is that the game is going in the right direction and I am expecting more interesting things. 

Cant wait for the full version to come out!!

In brief: short and intriguing. 

After one play through I wasn't completely sold that Project Kat reached it's 'unconventional' goal, but after finding most endings (and to avoid spoiling) I can say I'm definitely onboard; if, after the first play through, you find yourself wondering what the game is trying to achieve, maybe give it another run through. The game is just as short as it is intriguing, but a single play through will unlikely provide you much to think about. It is only in taking the prologue as a whole (recognising where, why and how the story can deviate), that it earns the self-proclaimed title 'unconventional.'

Looking forward to seeing what becomes of this series.

This game surprised me a lot. The graphics together with the background noises and music simply harmonized, so that sometimes you really got goose bumps in front of the pc. Although a short game of about an hour is very worthwhile to have played it once. What took some getting used to are the controls, but luckily you can change it in the settings. The puzzles were feasible even if you partly pondered something. Since it's just the prologue, I can hardly wait for Chapter 1. That's all and have a great day. Have fun playing <3

Got all ending and secrets, such a cute short game for what it is considering this is only the prologue to Paper Lily

8.5/10

Finally a good game. 

Beautiful artwork, nice atmosphere. It seems well written too. 

I hope this will be released soon, good job!
In Project Kat, you play as a sweet little girl who makes new friends [b]and nothing else significant happens.[/b]

I didn't expected to like this game much, because I'm neither a big fan of pixel art nor of horror games, but I'm happy that I played it.
The horror is more suble and the game is much more about exploration and finding the different endings than I thought. When I realized that you can influence the story quiet a bit and have different outcomes, I was motivated to find them. Some pathes are obvious while other a pretty well hidden. 

Probably one of the best free single player games on steam.

[b]8/10

I just finished playing the game and once I reached the end I was upset that there wasn't anymore to play. It is such a lovely game. I am in love with the graphics and the puzzle aspect of it all. I am also hugely into the whole ritual and horror type stuff so I am really excited for when chapter 1 comes out and I'm also looking forward to more chapters to come! 100% would recommend.
Great game, I generally hate horror games, but this was very interestingly laid out. Can't wait for the full game!
A short and surprisingly detailed RPG-Maker game, with unique dialogue for every small interaction. The writing and characters are great and I totes can't wait for the full game!!
I'm very easily scared so horror games aren't really my thing but holy fuck did i enjoy this! Gotta replay it again after I've calmed down but I can't wait for more!
short and sweet! really love the fun and creepy atmosphere. the art is very nice too

i loved it. the story is amazing and submersive. there is so much you can do and so many different endings and so much stuff hidden away. personally i've done all the endings and got all the achievements because it was so fun to see what you could have done. each path is so different and it's not too boring when you have a reliable save file. not to mention this is only a small part of the finished product! i wonder how incredible will this game be once finished. i only wish more people knew about it, so if anyone's wondering if it's worth it: did you like undertale, one shot, sally face and more along those lines? this game is 100% for you, get on it right now!

I loved it so much I was immediately going to buy the full version because I needed it to keep going! I'll be waiting until a full version comes out to buy immediately. I can't wait! Keeps you on the edge and is insanely creepy. Would 100% recommend playing through and giving it a try. If you like games like Omori and Undertale, I think you're gonna love this.

Such a very well written indie game and great artwork, love the 8bit gameplay. 
surprised it was free, story ends in two different ways from what i've seen! there might be more, so a few ways of more replay value. 
10/10 would recommend! :)
Everything from the graphics to the story is perfect, best indie game Ive ever played

A pretty interesting, cute and short horror game. The graphics were really nice for pixel art and I loved the character design. The music and sounds were nice as well. The story is also well done, especially for such a short game. I loved the premise and I really enjoyed the multiple endings. I do wish that there was some kind of maybe a gallery or an ending list in-game. It would be nice to see if I had grabbed all the endings or if I ended up missing any. I did like seeing that certain choices did change a few things in-game (such as the blackboard in the theater room). I didn't have any real issues while playing the game, beyond my own stupidness. For a prologue, I don't expect there to be much in the game, and I definitely don't expect a long game. For 3 hours, I was able to look around and beat the game a few times. 

Overall, if you're a fan of short horror games, then I'd suggest giving this game a try. It's free so you're not losing anything.
Found myself trying to work out all the different endings on my own. Was better than I was expecting. I'm sure the full game would be worth the time.
its a very interesting and unexpected game with so many options i hope the main game will come out soon

The first time I played this game I was constantly worrying about the choices I was making and kept overthinking every little choice I was given, this along with the atmosphere I have felt during my first blind playthrough and with the feel of despair wondering if I've fucked something up has made this a very enjoyable experience that I would recommend to everyone. Even if the game was short I was constantly worrying about the characters and the music being both soothing and unnerving has made this an even more enjoyable. Looking forward to the release of Paper Lily!
I loved the game but something i dont love is that the system requirements are wrong, you dont need an i5 nor 8GB RAM to play this

Very well made game. It's presented beautifully, has an engaging plot, hides interesting secrets, and does it all in the time it takes to watch a movie. Actually a lot shorter than that with how long movies are these days. 

As a free experience, it is absolutely worth your time. If you're at all interested in Paper Lily then you'd be silly to skip this.

Good art style and free, contains multiple endings for replay-ability but you might want to consult guide after one playthrough to reduce rerunning. Story and gameplay are interesting enough (and as the title suggests, it's the prologue of a full game).

Very good! It may not cost your money but it's definitely worth spending your time on.

A short, but pretty good horror game visually and story wise! It also has a good ending which makes it even better overall.

The pixel art style is also kinda unique and pretty cute!

I like the game so far.... its short but interesting. I love how the different puzzles may or may not change your fate later on in the game. So far I've played the bad ending. I am going to play it again to see the good ending.

I really liked this game! There is clearly a bigger plot going on. I got a few false endings and the true end, which btw, only intrigues me more.  

[spoiler] Also, about one of the false endings I got (the Girl's night out), I'd only say that the final cutscene was a little too long. Maybe some of that dialogue could be presented with more art for variety or maybe in some form of playability. At least so it doesn't feel that long. [/spoiler] 

Overall I really want to play the full game now! Will be waiting for its release!

This game gave me goosebumps; even though I knew it was a horror. The subtle sounds and the creepy shadows are very cool. I liked this game a lot and can't wait for the full version. If you like horror and like short games, this'll do nicely.

Also - side note: This is my 2nd 100% completion of a game, so pretty neat.

Pretty much: Like game, very scary, waiting for full version.

[b] NO SPOILERS [/b]
I really enjoyed the game, the slightly creepy atmosphere and the cute girls are one of my favourite pairings.
You have the opportunity to make your own decisions and think about what object can be useful for a given situation, the game doesn't completely guide you, but it gives you clues as to what you need to do to move forward.
My first run took about an hour, but to get all the achievements I did several.
I love the ability to save whenever you want and to have several save slots so you can load a precise save, although this was a short game so 3 slots were more than enough, but in the full game I'd like to have more than 3 slots available.
it was very interesting because i had to reason about my actions and not try random things, and then the game held that constant slight anxiety that completed the atmosphere, i really enjoyed the whole game, the gameplay, the choice of style and the designs, and i can't wait for the full game to come out.

If you are looking for a short game with a short but interesting story and some horror, I highly recommend this game

These are games I don't normally play, so when I downloaded it my hopes and expectations weren't high, but boy was I proven wrong. This game is truly something else, there were tons of Options some mattered and others were pointless but that was one of my favorite things, all the Actions and Option pointless or not really contributed to world building and fed Imagination. Closing and Opening the window has no impact on the story but it made the world feel all the more real. Another part I enjoyed was all the little secrets and alternate paths, they weren't too hard to find but were just hard enough to make me think. I am looking forward to the next chapters as they release and would be more than happy to Pay for the finished product. Anyone interested in a good game with a captivating story and solid mechanics this game is for you, 10/10.

Great, well made game. Though, I feel like some of the endings were a bit too specific to achieve. Other than though its really fun and looks very nice - the art style and overall design are both really good. Plus, Kat is quite the interesting character and I'd love to see more of her in the full game.

8/10

Very nice horror game. There aren't things that jump right at you like a jumpscare but the things that appear from time to time is just enough to send my spine tingling. They played around with the audio as well to give the extra suspense. Puzzles weren't that hard but I'm guessing these will in difficulty in the full game. With all that said, I can't wait for the full game!

tl;dr
• scary with no jumpscare
• easy puzzles
• can't wait for the full game :D

It's short, sweet and the atmosphere is excellent.
It gives me a ton of Kult:Divinity Lost vibes and that in itself is awesome. Sure the anime schoolgirl aesthetics might turn some off (and others on) but in the background there is a genuinely good atmospheric exploration game here and I truly recommend it as a short yet enjoyable experience on the occult side of things!

10/10 Would open the gateway again!

Great little game to get me into the spooky mood for upcoming Halloween season! 
It made me feel eerie and second guess if I was home alone, exactly what it should be doing, great mood setting!

The beginning was upbeat and the achievement puzzling took me a minute to figure out which was nice, making me have to play through more than once to see the different ending. All in all i really liked this and will be looking for more short multi-layered games similar in the future! 

8/10 - could do with a couple more puzzles
Its always nice to just kinda play a game that doesn't take hours to complete and this game fits that will be looking forward to the full game when it comes out
a really nice game in visuals, i love the music sounds too its very relaxing even tho there isn't really a story behind

I think this is one of my favourite games now.
I'm here mainly for the lore and I seriously can't wait for more. The thing I love the most about this game is probably the story/writing, it's just so well thought out. But I also greatly enjoy the gameplay and the spooky moments!
And the art is magnificent!!

very short and interesting game! the concept isn't that epic, but the twists will make you quite shocked.
can't wait for a full release.

This was a spooky and fun little game. The artwork is awesome, the story is super intriguing, it draws you in and makes you want to know more. The movement feels great, all the descriptions of the items you can interact with were fun, and some genuinely creepy stuff happens. I can't wait for the full game to be released!
